comments.commentBody:
Mr. Walker is correct in that the public sector unions need to be controlled.

In California the various unions for teachers, police, firefighters, correctional officers, highway patrol, etc. have such massive political power that they virtually form a fourth branch of government.

It hasn't ended up with teachers, police, and firefighters getting overpaid though, has it? It's not as if they get free health care for life, just for signing up, like the way all our representatives in congress do.

And your point is what? That unions are ruining opportunity, progress, and prosperity in California? California: where the most prestigious universities in the world are humming along; where the modern tech, tourism, and agriculture industries flourish in a dynamic economy--the 7th largest economy in the world. Too bad they also have teachers, firefighters, and police who earn good wages and benefits.
Who would want that?

While in Madison a few years back I was walking up State Street toward the capital when I noticed to the right at the top of state street - directly across the street from the capitol (and stinking up the atmosphere around Myles' Teddywedgers!) - an office for Koch Industries. I thought at that time that it was a very convenient location for that office. I wonder how many other state capitol buildings have Koch offices immediately adjacent to them?

Some things really need to be run or regulated by the federal government to assure every citizen gets a fair deal and to avoid having the population going from state to state to get, say, health care. We do not want to bring back the days when great coal burning power plants in the mid west released massive amount of pollution into the upper atmosphere that caused acid rain in the East or when some states gave their down and out citizens a one way buss ticket to a more generous state like, say NY.

3 million more people voted for the flawed candidate Clinton. If republicans are so confident America believes in their values then why do they gerrymander? Why all the voter suppression/ID laws? Why do they avoid town hall meetings?
At their very core they are cowards gaming the system.

The truth is that health care for everyone helps the economy. Medical bankruptcy is useless. Raising the minimum wage helps everyone. Environmental regulation saves lives, rivers and air quality. If Scott Walker was interested in truth he would be open to evidence. But he is afraid of the truth because he beholden to greedy millionaire polluters. Scott Walker is a coward.

Right on the mark. A combination of big money and rigging elections has given us a raft of GOP politicians whose main goal is upward redistribution of wealth. Walker's claim that the GOP is all about states rights is pure bunk. States rights and local control are invoked whenever convenient, scrapped when the locals do something the servants of the wealthy deplore, such as raise the minimum wage or impose a family leave policy. Taking health care, one shortcoming of the ACA was that it left too much to the states, where Republican governors and legislatures could cripple it and then blame the Democrats. Walker may be an honest politician in the sense that he stays bought, but otherwise he's the poster child for just what this country does not need. A national election demonstrated that quite clearly, as he was the first to drop out of the presidential contest; no wonder he prefers state-level politics.

Well absolutely on target. The electoral majority of people want a return to Federalism, and know that the Founders would be stunned, horrified at the role Washington now plays (demands) in all our lives.

All those buildings in DC, all those agencies, all those regulations, all those employees, ninety percent of whom are Democrats, the place awash in a tidal basin of unearned money. You walk the streets and wonder, how much of this could be eliminated and the wheels still go round? A rough estimate from this tax-paying tourist: about a good third, for a start. The inefficiency and complacency are staggering, I've friends who live there, I've been to the parties and conferences, I know. An unconscionable bureaucratic much ado about nothing. It's a no-brainer that this crowd does all it can to maintain and expand the bloat, though it's hard to imagine anyone satisfied going home at five from a meaningless job which gums up our lives and produces absolutely, positively, unequivocally ZERO.

Let's hope the Repubs now have what it takes to do their job. Ignore the shouts and the signs and the zombie masks and the faux rage. They'll be unemployed ciphers in 2018 if they don't.

"..a meaningless job which gums up our lives and produces absolutely, positively, unequivocally ZERO."

Though you don't name a single job, not one, ZERO.

By the way: 70% of the federal budget goes to pay FEDERAL entitlements like social security, which goes to average Americans. Republicans just want to eliminate as much of that as they can--by "returning" power to the states, you know...like it used to be, before "the liberals" ruined everything.

Nonsense.
The electoral majority wanted jobs, a President who tells the truth, and one whose spouse is not a philanderer. They will learn that the have gotten none of this -- except perhaps a chaste spouse.
The real majority knew this already, and did not vote for fraud.
You seem to like your bureaurcracy when it wears medals, and procures more weapons --- .the real zombie mask wearing death eaters, producing nothing but more insecurity.
I prefer those who keep my air and water clean, my food unadulterated, and prevent banksters, pharmacecutical, auto, telecommunications, and a whole host of cother corporate cheaters from ripping me off.
How about if the next time they do, I send the bill to you.

Ken, I'm so sorry that on your tourist visa trip to Washington you couldn't get your head around 'what's in it for Ken?' You couldn't imagine the synergy and complexity of 300 million Kens. The messy work of government aspires to insure Justice, Tranquility, general Welfare, and Liberty to you and all the other Kens, your fellow citizens. Most would like to just be left alone. Some squeak.  The ones with the most money squeak the loudest. They hire lobbyists, the "crowd that does all it can to maintain and expand the bloat." I humbly suggest Ken considers involvement in overturning Citizens United and getting at least some of the money out of the electoral process.

That formula does not actually work, and Walker knows this. He and Ryan are ideologues who hate labor unions, tenured professors and anyone else who is not an obedient soldier to big money interests. His presentation of the situation in Wisconsin is just wrong. Like all Republicans, he survives by dividing people. Stand strong here means do not listen. But I suggest he and his kind start to listen to the voices of people who are saying that government must work for us, not for the Koch Brothers and the Trump family.
Thank you!

You're not fighting for taxpayers - unless you are referring to the very wealthy. This has always been about the taxes collected from the rich and used to pay for health care for the disadvantaged. Trump will soon discover this truth, too, when the proposals from Ryan, et al, are revealed and the nation discovers that paying for "repeal and replace" will be impossible without getting a LOT of money from somewhere else.

They are giving a tax break to the rich, so it can't come from there. They are giving a tax break to corporations, so it can't come from there. They are raising "border fees" so some money will come from there - but wait those fees will be added onto prices for imported consumer goods - wonder who buys that sort of stuff?

Obama's ACA did incorporate a large scale transfer of wealth - from a relatively small number of wealthy people to a very, very large number of surprisingly unhealthy poor people (that's why the costs were a little higher than expected for the ACA). Seems like a morally defensible position when compared to what's about to happen next as the flow of money is away from the disadvantaged and into the pockets of those who certainly don't need any more.

Yes, Wisconsin is just like Indiana. More people are working than ever before.

Of course, our median income is the lowest it's been in 30 years, more children live in poverty than ever before. Pence's expansion of Medicaid was a huge success - because we have so many people who can't afford health care. Yep, it's a real joy here in the right to work states.

Republican arguments likes those pushed by Walker are, as always, counterfactual.  When Republicans control the Executive Branch, both the size of the government and deficits grow.  Look it up.  Fiscal conservatives and states' rights are only important to them when Democrats are in charge.

Governor Waljer, don't forget we have a common contract called the Constitution.  There are guarantees and rules which cover the whole country and set the character of the entire United States.   Deciding what must be for the whole and what is held by individual states is the constant question.  Expect your answers to that question to be be debated and contested furiously because in November, 2016, the majority of Americans voted against them.

The narrative that's emerging from Republicans is that liberals are a violent group. It strikes me as odd because we're so often also portrayed as effeminate, frail, and insert-other-homophobic-phrase-here.

So here we are, limp-wristed and mean, concerned about safe spaces and trigger warnings while also threatening Republicans' safety. This plays well into the right wing victim fantasy.

Republicans can show up armed with rifles and hand guns in a restaurant and they are simply defenders of freedom. They can shoot up pizza parlors based on "bad Intel" and kill Indian engineers and their leaders like Walker say very little. But if a liberal shows up in a pink hat to protest taking away healthcare from millions or removing collective bargaining rights for teachers she is vicious and out of control.

They actually believe it is intellectually sophisticated to believe mutually contradictory things at the same time, and they always expect to have a cake and eat it too.

Many Americans are many cards short of a full deck.

Ahhh the states, those incubators of inequality, sentries of the second amendment, stout supporters of school choice and budget crippling vouchers. These laboratories of the laissez faire and support for the status quo that are as different as California and Alabama or Texas and Texas. Yes, they should take on the exclusive responsibility for determining who can or should vote and whether or not workers have a right to organize. In our system of checks and balances the federal government ensures that the constitution reads the same in all 50 states. It's a matter of settled law. We fought a Civil War over that, to make the system of government clear but nothing is ever settled for some. I wish they'd do the honest thing and try to pass a constitutional amendment that supports just one of their inconsistent ideas. Then they'd see just how much support they really have.
States exist only to perpetuate unequal protection of law.
The alternative to Cleveland!
Russian state KGB mafia is very real, and the USA is just catching this cancer that already eats Europe alive. Google "schroeder gazprom" and "tillerson gazprom" to see what it's all about.

Calling for an investigation of Schumer based on one ancient photo is a deflection so ham-handed as to be laughable.

And in any case, the public already has ample information regarding Schumer's finances: His 2015 tax return is currently posted on his Senate website, a practice he has followed for a number of years.

So Trump, why don't you now go ahead and release yours? Chuck has. In fact, you should want to. Because if there are no shadowy Russian connections to hide, as you claim, then they should serve to exonerate you, and you can clear this mess up once and for all.
Trump is scared stiff to release his Tax Returns. There must be a way to have them subpoenaed on the grounds that the security of the country is at risk.

From this weeks Economist
This is a typical Putinstan.

(The Borowitz Report) from Moscow : —Russian President Vladimir Putin is “starting to get concerned” that the puppets he installed in the executive branch of the U.S. government “might not be up to the task at hand,” sources confirmed on Tuesday.

According to the sources, the flameout of the national-security adviser Michael Flynn was only the most recent event that has caused Putin to wonder if the figureheads he propelled into office are “just too dim-witted” to serve the goals of the Russian Federation. "

A source close to Putin said. “You want to choose someone who’s dumb enough to be manipulated, but not so dumb that he can’t find the light switches.”

Putin is reportedly willing to have a “wait and see” attitude with his current puppets, but, if things do not improve markedly, he will not hesitate to “make some changes,” the source said..

Re: your last line - there's tons of evidence.  Russian hackers wrote countless fake news reports about Hillary and disseminated them on social media.  Thousands of people read them and believed them.  Then there's the hack of the DNC and Jon Pidesta's e-mails, which, again, were widely distributed - all unflattering to Clinton.  There's no way to deny these things didn't influence voters.

A very disturbing trend. Michael Flynn lied, Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Donald trump are lying, an entire administration of liars. Trump call this a witch hunt. Two witches were netted in the hunt and the ring leader of the witches is still at large.

The free press and friends of the people will keep telling the truth as they are the
only semblance of Democracy remaining.

Shane and Kramer casually observe: "Part of the problem underlying disputes over such contacts may be Mr. Trump’s pugnacious style, which usually leaves little room for nuance." Are you just kidding me?  There's a heck of a lot more wrong here than Trump's pugnacious style. Then there's one of the commenters: "those who oppose Mr. Trump and want to see the Trump Era end quickly should reflect on whether championing a new Cold War is the best way to do that ... Let's also reflect on why Trump won an election he should have lost in a landslide: Russia is not responsible for that." Oh, it isn't? I think the whole point is,  no one can be sure.  I think if anyone or any nation improperly swayed a US election, that is a matter of intense and legitimate concern. Oh yes, I admit, we do it to other nations and have done it for years (though from British Columbia, I'm an American too). It is extremely immoral if not outright evil, and with the US meddling in that way, it figures that sooner or later it would be done to the US. But there's more.  There's the vivid possibility that Trump may have personal interests entwined with Russia, which would distort his judgement on international affairs and, if so, would endanger us all. I'm glad most people are outraged about this, the  indifference coming from some directions is amazing.

Tax returns are private. Trump is not getting away with anything by not showing them. Why subject himself to the lies and innuendos that surrounded Romney's tax returns?

If there is anything wrong with Trump's tax returns, it's up to the IRS to correct it.

It seems that Pelosi and McCaskill "met" the ambassador in the sense that they were present at a large gathering of senators and ambassadors. They did not have one-on-one meetings with the Russian ambassador, as Sessions did.

This isn't one article, it's two. The first half is a cohesive narrative about contacts that the author says are the subject of "intense scrutiny." The second half undermines the first half of the article completely by seemingly arguing that there is less to the matter of the Trump campaign's contacts with the Russian government than meets the eye.

The quote from the former ambassador to Moscow is positively asinine. He wags his finger at your readers that we need to calm down about the Trumps and the Russians, precisely at the time when facts are pouring out, because all this attention in the US to Russia is making us unpopular in Moscow. I'm not sure I understand why this is in this article.

Similarly, what is the point of the long account of the meeting between Greenblatt and a pro-Putin rabbi in Moscow? This supports the Ambassador's comments that we are all being paranoid.

Let's just worry about getting all the facts out and we can decide later what was important and what wasn't.
I suppose you thought democracy was in danger during the first two years of Obama's term when the Democrats controlled the White House and both Houses of Congress?

Trump supporters are willing to stand by him even after all these revelations about contacts with Russia.  It makes you wonder if they have ever opened a history book and read how vicious and deadly the dictators have been--just in recent years!  So many flat-out dumb Americans.

If the Russians can get the U.S to lift the sanctions, Poof! Money and power for the 1% and the oligarchs.

The GOP will not save America.

Make America Great?

We must move forward not backwards.

This is so tiring.
